Situation1: Their partner had a mildly stressful day at work and mentions it casually.
Situation2: They guide a patient on proper usage and potential side effects of a new prescription medication.
Story: I glanced at the clock as I finished counseling a patient about their new medication, carefully explaining the side effects and answering their anxious questions. My phone buzzed in my pocket—my husband’s name flashed on the screen. He’d had a rough day, he’d said earlier, his voice tired but trying to sound upbeat. I knew he needed me to listen, to offer comfort, to be present. But the patient in front of me looked worried, clutching their prescription bag, clearly needing reassurance and guidance. My mind raced, torn between the urge to step away and call my husband, to be the supportive wife he deserved, and the responsibility to my patient, who depended on my expertise and calm. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, my heart pulled in two directions, each role demanding my full attention at the same moment. I took a deep breath, feeling the conflict twist inside me, knowing I couldn’t give both what they needed right now.
